title: 108_hr3774
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Resilience Development Act of 2003". The Congress emphasizes the importance of analyzing terrorism preparedness to address psychological consequences and enhance resilience. Research shows effective ways to minimize the damaging psychological impact of terrorism. After the September 11, 2001 attacks, Americans, including children, experienced significant stress symptoms. Clinicians should be prepared to help individuals with trauma-related stress symptoms. Lessons from past terrorist attacks indicate that psychological casualties from chemical attacks may outnumber physical casualties. The 2001 anthrax attacks should motivate health departments, healthcare organizations, and clinicians to collaborate. According to the National Advisory Committee on Children and Terrorism, the psychological impact of terrorism is significant, especially on children and families. There is a need for increased focus on promoting family and community resilience in disaster planning. Schools play a crucial role in addressing terrorism, as highlighted in recommendations to the Secretary. Schools are crucial in addressing terrorism as they are often affected by it due to the large population present. Emergency management plans in schools should align with broader public health and emergency response efforts. Healthcare providers are seeing an increase in patients with physical symptoms masking anxiety or depression in the face of growing terrorism threats. Efforts and funding are needed to address these challenges. Efforts and funding are needed to address the psychological consequences associated with bioterrorism. Integration of mental health into public health efforts is critical in addressing the Nation's psychological needs regarding terrorism. The goals outlined in Section 3 focus on addressing the psychological consequences of bioterrorism and integrating mental health into public health efforts to meet the nation's needs regarding terrorism. The Act aims to identify effective strategies for responding to the impacts of terrorism, coordinate government agencies in developing programs to increase psychological resilience, and support the Department of Homeland Security in implementing protocols to address psychological aspects of terrorism. The Act aims to increase psychological resilience and respond to the impacts of terrorism by integrating mental health and public health emergency preparedness efforts in the United States. It also focuses on enabling states and localities to effectively address the behavioral, cognitive, and emotional impacts of terrorism in disaster management. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include a new section establishing an Interagency Task Force on National Resilience. The Secretary will lead an interagency task force to enhance the psychological resilience of the American public and improve government response to the impacts of terrorism. Task force members include key health and emergency preparedness officials. The task force duties include coordinating efforts of various health agencies to develop programs for increasing psychological resilience and responding to the impacts of terrorism. The Health and Human Service's task force is responsible for consulting with various departments and organizations to integrate programs for increasing psychological resilience and responding to the impacts of terrorism. The task force consults with agencies, Department of Education, and states/local governments to develop strategies for responding to the impacts of terrorism on children and increasing psychological resilience. Developing strategies for enhancing psychological resilience and disaster management in response to terrorism, including integrating science-based programs and protocols. Providing recommendations to strengthen terrorism preparedness initiatives by integrating programs across relevant departments and agencies. The task force will meet at least 4 times a year and will be staffed as necessary to perform its duties related to enhancing psychological resilience and disaster management in response to terrorism. SEC. 5. ACTIVITIES OF STATES, DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, AND TERRITORIES REGARDING NATIONAL RESILIENCE. To enhance national resilience, amendments are made to the Public Health Service Act and the USA Patriot Act. The changes aim to empower State mental health authorities to understand and manage emotional, behavioral, and cognitive responses to disasters, increasing psychological resilience and mitigating distress reactions in the event of an attack on the United States. The USA PATRIOT Act of 2001 is amended to allow grants to be used for purchasing, constructing, and enabling State mental health authorities to manage responses to disasters. The USA PATRIOT Act of 2001 is amended to allow grants for enhancing cognitive responses to disasters, increasing psychological resilience, and mitigating distress reactions in the public in the event of an attack on the United States. SEC. 6 of the Homeland Security Act is amended to include considerations for psychological injury and trauma consequences. SEC. 7 requires annual reports from the Secretaries of HHS and Homeland Security. The Secretaries of Health and Human Services and Homeland Security must submit an annual report to Congress, including recommendations from an interagency task force, steps taken to implement those recommendations, explanations for any rejections, and other actions to achieve the goals of the Act.
